ProcedureHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: PROC TRANTAB TABLE=table-name <NLS>;  
    CLEAR <ONE|TWO|BOTH>;  
    INVERSE;  
    LIST <ONE|TWO|BOTH>;  
    LOAD TABLE=table-name <NLS>;  
    REPLACE position value-1<...value-n>;  
    SAVE <TABLE=table-name> <ONE|TWO|BOTH>;  
    SWAP;
  
The TRANTAB procedure creates, edits, and displays customized translation tables. 
In addition, you can use PROC TRANTAB to view and modify translation tables that 
are supplied by SAS. These SAS supplied tables are stored in the SASHELP.HOST catalog. 
Any translation table that you create or customize is stored in your SASUSER.PROFILE 
catalog. Translation tables have an entry type of TRANTAB.

Translation tables are operating environment-specific SAS catalog entries that are 
used to translate the values of one (coded) character set to another. A translation 
table has two halves: table one provides a translation, such as ASCII to EBCDIC; table 
two provides the inverse (or reverse) translation, such as EBCDIC to ASCII. Each half 
of a translation table is an array of 256 two-digit positions, each of which contains 
a one-byte unsigned number that corresponds to a coded character.

The SAS System uses translation tables for the following purposes: 

  o determining the collating sequence in the SORT procedure

  o performing transport-format translations when you transfer files with the CPORT 
    and CIMPORT procedures

  o performing translations between operating environments when you access remote data 
    in SAS/CONNECT or SAS/SHARE software

  o facilitating data communications between the operating environment and a graphics 
    device when you run SAS/GRAPH software in an IBM environment

  o accommodating national language character sets other than U.S. English.

PROC TRANTAB produces no output. It can display translation tables and notes in the SAS log.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the table you listed in the TABLE= argument is one of five special internal translation tables provided with
every copy of the SAS System.
Specifies the translation table to create, edit, or display.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: The local-to-transport format translation table (used by the CPORT procedure
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: The transport-to-local format translation table (used by the CIMPORT procedure
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: The lowercase-to-uppercase translation table (used by the UPCASE function)
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: The uppercase-to-lowercase translation table (used by the LOWCASE macro
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: The character classification table (used internally), which contains flag bytes that correspond to each character position that indicate the class or classes to which each character belongs.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: CLEAR <ONE|TWO|BOTH>; 
      
Sets all positions in the translation table to zero; used when you create a new table.

[Syntax: INVERSE;] 
      
Creates an inverse of table 1 in a translation table; that is, it creates table 2.

Syntax: LIST <ONE|TWO|BOTH>;  
      
Displays in the SAS log a translation table in hexadecimal representation.

Syntax: LOAD TABLE=table-name <NLS>; 
      
Loads a translation table into memory for editing.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata: Specifies that the table you listed in the TABLE= argument is one of five special internal translation tables provided with SAS.
Specifies the name of an existing translation table to be edited.

StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: The local-to-transport format translation table (used by the CPORT procedure
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: The transport-to-local format translation table (used by the CIMPORT procedure
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: The lowercase-to-uppercase translation table (used by the UPCASE function)
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: The uppercase-to-lowercase translation table (used by the LOWCASE macro
StatementOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: The character classification table (used internally), which contains flag bytes that correspond to each character position that indicate the class or classes to which each character belongs.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SAVE <TABLE=table-name> <ONE|TWO|BOTH>;
      
Saves the translation table in your SASUSER.PROFILE catalog.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: TABLE=table-name] 
          
Specifies the name under which the current table is to be saved. The name must 
be a valid one-level SAS name.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: SWAP; 
      
Exchanges table 1 with table 2 to enable you to edit positions 256 through 511.
